Preface
Management System for this RMP
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared for the Fresh Express ammonia refrigeration system located at 2370 W. Warrior Trail in Grand Prairie, Texas.  This RMP was developed to comply with the following requirements:
* Accidental Release Prevention requirements for Risk Management Programs under Clean Air Act Section 112(r), pursuant to Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR), Part 68.
* Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, pursuant to Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations (29 CFR), Subpart H - 1910.119.
Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.15, a management system has been developed for this RMP.  The Maintenance Manager has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of RMP elements.  This position has d

irect supervisory responsibility for the operations and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.  This position coordinates RMP implementation by interaction with the site's Maintenance Technicians, Safety Manager and contractors involved in the design, operation and maintenance of the system.

Executive Summary
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  The Safety Manager for the Fresh Express Grand Prairie site ensures that safe practices are followed in operations involving hazardous materials. This site has established emergency procedures and coordinates with the local Fire Department and a local Emergency Response Team (to be contracted) to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, which include response to emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system covered by this RMP.  The site has written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 
Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The Fresh Express facility covered by this RMP is located at 2370 W. Warrior Trail in Grand Prairie, Texas.  The facility receives produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, transported and distributed from the site.
The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.  One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce at various temperatures. The total charge to this refrigeration system is estimated at 15,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Since the amount of ammonia in the system exceeds the RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, the process that uses the ammonia is covered by the RMP requirements.
Release Scenarios1
Worst-Case Release Scenario
In this worst-case release scenario, the total ammonia refrigeration system charge of approximately 15,000 pounds is

assumed to be released within 10 minutes from the high-pressure receiver resulting from a breach of containment.  The worst-case release rate would therefore be approximately 1,500 pounds of ammonia per minute.  No passive mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario. Since the vessel is located outdoors (i.e., mounted on the roof), no mitigation measures were considered.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario would be 0.7 mile.  
Alternative Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario was derived from the results of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study conducted at Fresh Express in December 2004.  The scenario chosen is a failed pressure relief valve resulting from overpressurization of the high pressure receiver.  Since the vessel is located outdoors (i.e., mounted on the roof), no mitigation measures were considered.  Based on the calculated release rate of 1417 pounds of ammonia per minute and assuming that the entire system charge is released, the estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for this alternative release scenario would be 0.4 mile.
Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Prevention of accidental ammonia releases at Fresh Express is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications prior to their occurrence, and the regular operation, maintenance and monitoring of the system.  This includes:
* Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction of the system, as well as in the event of system modifications through a management of change process.
* Performance of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) at least once every five years using accurate process safety information.
* Implementation of operating, maintenance and monitoring procedures. 
* Training of system operations and mainten

ance personnel, as well as ongoing training of the on-site Chemical Response Team.  
* Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to hot work permit program requirements to ensure mechanical integrity.
* Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols.
* Use of qualified contractors for work on the system.
The detailed Prevention Program for this system is contained in a supporting document, which is to be maintained at by the site by the Site Safety Manager.
Five Year Accident History
According to Fresh Express personnel, no ammonia releases resulting in on-site or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have occurred since the installation of the ammonia refrigeration system. 
Emergency Response Program
This Grand Prairie facility has established emergency procedures and coordinates with the local Fire Department and a contracted local Emergency Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, which include response to emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system covered by this RMP.  
The Emergency Response procedures are accessible at the site, and copies are maintained in the Grand Prairie Safety Manager's files.  The document describes response procedures for various emergency scenarios, including the mitigation of hazardous material releases, agency notification procedures in the event of a hazardous material release, and emergency equipment available at the site.

Plan Overview
If an ammonia release poses a potential environmental, safety or health hazard to Fresh Express employees or the public, the Fresh Express Safety Manager or Incident Commander is to contact the Grand Prairie Fire Department and the appropriate medical care provider.  The Grand Prairie Fire Department is to assume command of the incident upon arrival.  
Notification of other agencies will be made if the release quantity exceeds the reporting threshold.  Evacuation of the facility in the event of an ammonia release follows the evacuation procedures for other types of emergencies.  Employees are drilled in evacuation procedures annually.  Fresh Express employees may not attempt to remove personnel from areas that might expose them to hazardous levels of ammonia.  Persons who can move to uncontaminated areas will receive basic first aid/CPR and care from the Grand Prairie Fire Department Emergency Medical Service (EMS).  An MSDS is to be provided to the EMS accompanying the victim to the hospital.
Other Emergency Requirements
In addition to the RMP requirements, the facility is subject to the Emergency Action Plan (29 CFR 1910.38) and Fire Prevention Plan (29 CFR 1910.39) requirements, which pertain to emergency planning.

Section 2
Offsite Consequence Analysis Summary
Because the

ammonia refrigeration system is considered a Program 3 process, at least one worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario have been analyzed for this RMP.
Release Scenarios1
The worst-case and alternative release scenarios chosen for the ammonia refrigeration system are described below.  A tabular summary of the release scenario data and results is presented at the end of this section.
Worst-Case Scenario
The worst-case release scenario defined by the RMP regulations (19 CCR 2750.3) for ammonia used in this process is as follows:  "For regulated toxic substances that are normally gases at ambient temperature and handled as a gas or liquid under pressure, the owner or operator shall assume that the quantity in the vessel or pipe (whichever is greater) is released as a gas over 10 minutes."  In this worst-case scenario, the total system charge is assumed to be released within 10 minutes from the high-pressure receiver resulting from a breach of containment, based on the system design.  
Fresh Express has determined that the current total system charge is approximately 15,000 pounds.  The worst-case release rate would therefore be approximately 1,500 pounds of ammonia per minute.  No passive mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario. Since the vessel is located outdoors (i.e., mounted on the roof), no mitigation measures were considered.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario would be 0.7 mile.
Alternative Scenario
Pursuant to RMP regulations, the alternative release scenario was identified as that which is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario, and that which will reach an endpoint offsite.  The alternative release scenario used meteorological conditions more representative of the site than those used for the worst-case scenario.  The alternative release scenario was derived from the results of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) stu

dy conducted at Fresh Express in December 2004.  
The scenario chosen is a failed pressure relief valve resulting from overpressurization of the high pressure receiver.  The 3/4" pressure relief valve is rated at 250 psig.  Since the vessel is located outdoors (i.e., mounted on the roof), no mitigation measures were considered.  Based on the calculated release rate of 1417 pounds of ammonia per minute and assuming that the entire system charge is released, the estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for this alternative release scenario would be 0.4 mile.
Release Scenario Map
The figure presented at the end of this section depicts the above release scenarios, plotted on a map of the area generated by LandView(r) 6 desktop mapping program.
Offsite Impacts
As required by the RMP regulations, the populations that fall within the circles defined by the distance to toxic endpoints for both the worst-case and alternative release scenarios have been estimated using LandView(6 desktop mapping program.  Population data in the program is based on Census 2000.
Residential Populations
The LandView(6 desktop mapping program was used to pinpoint the Fresh Express facility and estimate populations within the release scenario radius.  Using the population estimator within the LandView(6 program, it was determined by the Block Group Proration method that approximately 2,928 people reside within the 0.7-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario, and approximately 933 people reside within the 0.4-mile radius of the alternative release scenario. A public school is also located within the 0.4 mile radius of the alternative release scenario.
Other Public Receptors
In addition to residences, the presence of institutions (schools, hospitals, long term health care facilities, child day care facilities, prisons), parks and recreational areas, and major commercial, office, and industrial buildings must be noted in the RMP.  Based on review of the LandView(6 program data, there are two h

eliports and one airport within the 0.7-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario. 
Environmental Receptors
Environmental receptors that must be noted in the RMP are natural areas, such as national or state parks, forests or monuments; wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges or areas; and Federal wilderness areas.  Based on review of the LandView(6 program data, there are two creeks within the 0.7-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario, and only one of these two creeks (i.e., Kirby Creek) is located within the 0.4 mile radius of the alternative release scenario.

Section 3    
Five-year Accident History
According to Fresh Express personnel, no ammonia releases resulting in on-site or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have occurred since the installation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  
According to available facility incident records and based on information gathered from the PHA study conducted in December 2004, a few minor incidents have occurred since the ammonia system was initially operated in 2000.  These incidents include:
* A leaky gauge on the low pressure receiver, which released less than 5 pounds of ammonia.  An evacuation was determined to be unnecessary, and the gauge was replaced.
* A condenser pump failure caused by a high pressure condition one summer, in which the pump was replaced.
* A leaky gas seal on the recirculator pump, which was most likely the result of wear, was replaced.  
According to facility personnel, these incidents resulted in minor ammonia leaks, if any.  As part of the preventative maintenance of the refrigeration system, these equipment components generally are included in periodic inspections to assess their working conditions.

(f) Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) established for the ammonia refrigeration system are to be reviewed at least annually or as changes occur (whichever is sooner).  These SOPs are incorporated by reference into the Prevention Program document supporting this R

MP, and are maintained by the Facilities Maintenance Department.  These procedures are in place for the following activities:  Startup, Routine Operation, and Shutdown.  There is no Temporary Operation applicable to the system.  Each procedure contains steps for each applicable operating phase, and lists operating limits and hazard consequences of deviation where they are applicable.  A general operating procedure stating safety and health considerations (including exposure hazards/prevention measures) and describing safety systems has also been developed.  

(g) The ammonia supplier provides training to its own operators and drivers who have responsibility for transporting ammonia to and offloading ammonia at customer sites.  The types of competency testing used by the supplier for its employees include written tests, skills demonstration and observation to ensure that these employees are able to perform their duties in a safe manner.  

Fresh Express and contracted ammonia system operations and maintenance personnel have extensive ammonia refrigeration system experience.  The type of competency testing used includes skills demonstration and observation.  Specific training related to Fresh Express' ammonia refrigeration system is to be completed prior to operation or maintenance of the system.

(h) Ammonia refrigeration system maintenance procedures are to be reviewed at least annually or as changes occur (whichever is sooner).  Maintenance is performed by Fresh Express employees and/or contractors as per manufacturer recommendations and established procedures.  Fresh Express is to inspect and monitor the system on a regular basis.  These inspections are to be documented, and records of these inspections are to be reviewed and maintained by the Facilities Maintenance Department.  

(i) Initial development of management of change procedures related to the ammonia refrigeration system resulted from the compliance requirement for Fresh Express to develop a Program 3 P

revention Program that includes these procedures.

(j) The most recent pre-startup review of the ammonia refrigeration system occurred prior to its initial operation in 2000.

(k) RMP compliance audits are to be conducted in the future at least once every three years, with the first one to be conducted in April 2008.  

(l) To-date, few minor incidents related to the covered process have occurred.  According to facility personnel, these incidents have not resulted in onsite or offsite environmental, health or safety impacts. 

For incidents involving injuires, Fresh Express's normal incident investigation process begins through notification of the injured employee's supervisor or manager, who contacts the Safety Manager.  Otherwise, ammonia system related incidents are to be documented on Ammonia Release Response forms.  Both processes includes identification of root cause and corrective action related to the incident.

Management System for this RMP

This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has bee

n prepared for the Fresh Express ammonia refrigeration system located at 2370 W. Warrior Trail in Grand Prairie, Texas.  This RMP was developed to comply with the following requirements:

* Accidental Release Prevention requirements for Risk Management Programs under Clean Air Act Section 112(r), pursuant to Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR), Part 68.

* Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, pursuant to Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations (29 CFR), Subpart H - 1910.119.

Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.15, a management system has been developed for this RMP.  The Maintenance Manager has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of RMP elements. This position coordinates RMP implementation by interaction with the site's Maintenance Technicians, Safety Manager and contractors involved in the design, operation and maintenance of the system.



Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  The Safety Manager for the Fresh Express Grand Prairie site ensures that safe practices are followed in operations involving hazardous materials. This site has established emergency procedures and coordinates with the local Fire Department and a local Emergency Response Team (to be contracted) to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, which include response to emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system covered by this RMP.  The site has written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Fresh Express facility covered by this RMP is located at 2370 W. Warrior Trail in Grand Prairie,

Texas.  The facility receives produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, transported and distributed from the site.

The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.  One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce at various temperatures. The total charge to this refrigeration system is estimated at 15,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Since the amount of ammonia in the system exceeds the RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, the process that uses the ammonia is covered by the RMP requirements.

Release Scenarios1

Worst-Case Release Scenario

In this worst-case release scenario, the total ammonia refrigeration system charge of approximately 15,000 pounds is assumed to be released within 10 minutes from the high-pressure receiver resulting from a breach of containment.  The worst-case release rate would therefore be approximately 1,500 pounds of ammonia per minute.  No passive mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario. Since the vessel is located outdoors (i.e., mounted on the roof), no mitigation measures were considered.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario would be 0.7 mile.  

Alternative Release Scenario

The alternative release scenario was derived from the results of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study conducted at Fresh Express in December 2004.  The scenario chosen is a failed pressure relief valve resulting from overpressurization of the high pressure receiver.  Since the vessel is located outdoors (i.e., mounted on the roof), no mitigation measures were considered.  Based on the calculated release rate of 1417 pounds of ammonia per minute and assuming that the entire system charge is released, the estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for this alternative release scenario would be 0.4 mile.

ps

* Use of qualified contractors for work on the system.

The detailed Prevention Program for this system is contained in a supporting document, which is to be maintained at by the site by the Site Safety Manager.

Section 2

Offsite Consequence Analysis Summary

Because the ammonia refrigeration system is considered a Program 3 process, at least one worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario have been analyzed for this RMP.

Release Scenarios1

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios chosen for the ammonia refrigeration system are described below.  A tabular summary of the release scenario data and results is presented at the end of this section.

Worst-Case Scenario

The worst-case release scenario defined by the RMP regulations (19 CCR 2750.3) for ammonia used in this process is as follows:  "For regulated toxic substances that are normally gases at ambient temperature and handled as a gas or liquid under pressure, the owner or operator shall assume that the quantity in the vessel or pipe (whichever is greater) is released as a gas over 10 minutes."  In this worst-case scenario, the total system charge is assumed to be released within 10 minutes from the high-p

ressure receiver resulting from a breach of containment, based on the system design.  

Fresh Express has determined that the current total system charge is approximately 15,000 pounds.  The worst-case release rate would therefore be approximately 1,500 pounds of ammonia per minute.  No passive mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario. Since the vessel is located outdoors (i.e., mounted on the roof), no mitigation measures were considered.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario would be 0.7 mile.

Alternative Scenario

Pursuant to RMP regulations, the alternative release scenario was identified as that which is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario, and that which will reach an endpoint offsite.  The alternative release scenario used meteorological conditions more representative of the site than those used for the worst-case scenario.  The alternative release scenario was derived from the results of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study conducted at Fresh Express in December 2004.  

The scenario chosen is a failed pressure relief valve resulting from overpressurization of the high pressure receiver.  The 3/4" pressure relief valve is rated at 250 psig.  Since the vessel is located outdoors (i.e., mounted on the roof), no mitigation measures were considered.  Based on the calculated release rate of 1417 pounds of ammonia per minute and assuming that the entire system charge is released, the estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for this alternative release scenario would be 0.4 mile.

Release Scenario Map

The figure presented at the end of this section depicts the above release scenarios, plotted on a map of the area generated by LandView(r) 6 desktop mapping program.

Offsite Impacts

As required by the RMP regulations, the populations that fall within the circles defined by the distance to toxic endpoints for both the worst-case and alternat

ive release scenarios have been estimated using LandView(6 desktop mapping program.  Population data in the program is based on Census 2000.

Residential Populations

The LandView(6 desktop mapping program was used to pinpoint the Fresh Express facility and estimate populations within the release scenario radius.  Using the population estimator within the LandView(6 program, it was determined by the Block Group Proration method that approximately 2,928 people reside within the 0.7-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario, and approximately 933 people reside within the 0.4-mile radius of the alternative release scenario. A public school is also located within the 0.4 mile radius of the alternative release scenario.

Other Public Receptors

In addition to residences, the presence of institutions (schools, hospitals, long term health care facilities, child day care facilities, prisons), parks and recreational areas, and major commercial, office, and industrial buildings must be noted in the RMP.  Based on review of the LandView(6 program data, there are two heliports and one airport within the 0.7-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario. 

Environmental Receptors

Environmental receptors that must be noted in the RMP are natural areas, such as national or state parks, forests or monuments; wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges or areas; and Federal wilderness areas.  Based on review of the LandView(6 program data, there are two creeks within the 0.7-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario, and only one of these two creeks (i.e., Kirby Creek) is located within the 0.4 mile radius of the alternative release scenario.

Section 3    

Five-year Accident History

According to Fresh Express personnel, no ammonia releases resulting in on-site or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have occurred since the installation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  

According to available facility incident records and based on information gathered from the PHA study conducted in December 2004, a few minor incidents have occurred since the ammonia system was initially operated in 2000.  These incidents include:

* A leaky gauge on the low pressure receiver, which released less than 5 pounds of ammonia.  An evacuation was determined to be unnecessary, and the gauge was replaced.

* A condenser pump failure caused by a high pressure condition one summer, in which the pump was replaced.

* A leaky gas seal on the recirculator pump, which was most likely the result of wear, was replaced.  

According to facility personnel, these incidents resulted in minor ammonia leaks, if any.  As part of the preventative maintenance of the refrigeration system, these equipment components generally are included in periodic inspections to assess their working conditions.

Emergency Response Program Summary

Fresh Express's Grand Prairie facility has an established Emergency Response Plan.  The date of the most recent review of this plan was in December 2004.  Fresh Express is to conduct emergency response training and drills for employees on an annual basis.   



The written plan and emergency procedures for ammonia releases or spills include the following information as required by the RMP:

* Actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of ammonia

* Procedures for informing the public and local agencies responsible for responding to accidental releases

* Information on emergency health care.



The local emergency response agencies (e.g., fire, police, ambulance) and contracted emergency response team are to be contacted by Fresh Express as necessary to coordinate emergency response efforts in accordance with the Emergency Response Plan.  

Plan Overview

If an ammonia release poses a potential environmental, safety or health hazard to Fresh Express employees or the public, the Fresh Express Safety Manager or Incident Commander is to contact the Grand Prairie Fire Department and the appropriate medical care provider.  The Grand Prairie Fire Department is to assume command of the incident upon arrival.  

Notification of other agencies will be made if the release quantity exceeds the reporting threshold.  Evacuation of the facility in the event of an ammonia release follows the evacuation procedures for other types of emergencies.  Employees are drilled in e

vacuation procedures annually.  Fresh Express employees may not attempt to remove personnel from areas that might expose them to hazardous levels of ammonia.  Persons who can move to uncontaminated areas will receive basic first aid/CPR and care from the Grand Prairie Fire Department Emergency Medical Service (EMS).  An MSDS is to be provided to the EMS accompanying the victim to the hospital.

Other Emergency Requirements

In addition to the RMP requirements, the facility is subject to the Emergency Action Plan (29 CFR 1910.38) and Fire Prevention Plan (29 CFR 1910.39) requirements, which pertain to emergency planning.
